newsitem.title: USA: Plains fed cattle market not well tested- feedlots.
newsitem.headline: Plains fed cattle market not well tested- feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets Tuesday were extremely slow, with too few slaughter steers or heifers trading to establish a market, feedlot sources said.
There was one load of 50 head of Holstein steers sold in Kansas, discounted to $61.00 per cwt, according to USDA.
Regular slaughter steers and heifers last traded Monday at $71.00, with packer bids at that level going against asking levels of $72.00 to $73.00.
Prices were expected to be supported by continued light supplies of finished cattle, the sources said.

Feedlot cattle prices also were expected to be lifted by ongoing strength in boxed beef prices, especially in choice grade cuts, because of a shortage of high yielding cattle, the feedlot sources said.
Increased profitability due to lower feed costs and strong packer demand the last two weeks encouraged feedlots to sell cattle as much as 20 to 30 days ahead of schedule.
Beef prices at midday were quoted up $1.71 to $1.85 per cwt for choice grades and up $0.62 to $0.89 for selects, according to USDA. There were 106 fabricated loads sold.
